title: Bukito Y-Axis Motor Mount Shielded OpenBuild V-Slot Synchromesh Gear

description.text:
If you travel to rugged and rough areas then this Mount is for you. This mount replaces the Deezemaker Bukito stock acrylic Y-Axis motor mount and is a direct bolt in using existing stock parts. This fits in the Open Build V-Slot rail with zero lateral movement.
I made this to be a bit stronger and add a little protection to the Synchromesh gear and cable from side impacts due to rough handling or travel.
UPDATE: 9/25/2014: I wanted to thicken up the shield a bit and round off the corners so I published a V2 STL file but I have yet to print and test it. I won't be able to get to it for another 2 weeks. If you try and and it works fine. Let me know and I'll make it permanent.
Suggest printing with 65% or more infill for rigidity. No supports were needed. When assembling, it helps to install the motor last.

title: MakerScanner v0.3 B&D; Laser Line Level mount

description.text: This is a modification of the MakerScanner v0.3 scanner for the BDL220S Black & Decker Laser Line Level with Wall Mount. http://www.blackanddecker.com/power-tools/BDL220S.aspx It\'s designed to use the wall mount\'s existing magnetic rotational bearing. I chose this as it was one of the cheapest laser line levels at my local hardware store (this is carried at Lowe\'s and Ace Hardware as far as I could tell online) Because of the integration of the wall mount, you get a very solid, very smoothly rotating scanner. The BDL220S base unit is removeable for transport and use as intended. If you\'d like to still be able to use the wall mount, Black and Decker sells extra base units from their parts replacement center: http://www.blackanddeckerservicenet.com/Products/PartDetails.aspx?partid=242704

I haven\'t finished my makerscanner yet - my hot end clogged trying to print some of the other pieces and I haven\'t quite dialed in my replacement (makergear .35 bighead) yet...  I\'ll update the instructions with any other information when I fix it.  The center line and pivot of the laser should be right on and true using this method (as opposed to the more fallible laser module clamp - you really want the laser and the pivot point lined up for accuracy), but as I haven\'t used it yet, your mileage may vary...
Lightly sand the inside of the tab cutouts until the wall mount fits snugly.  Make sure the center pivot of the wall mount is pointing down when you press fit the two together.  I didn\'t have to use any glue - just a little persuasion (the name of my rubber mallet) and those two pieces are firmly and solidly interconnected.
I had to reverse the center alignment slot, but orientation isn\'t crucial.  Print a laser mount base from the MakerScanner 0.3 and line the top up with the base.  If you prefer, you can drill out the channel on the two pieces and use a 3mm steel rod to guarantee alignment.  As orientation isn\'t critical (and at this point you can still turn the angle measurement dial), I just eyeballed straight down the channel, got the alignment good enough and applied some superglue around the edge of the seam while applying light pressure for 5-10 minutes.
Your makerscanner will be functional without the following alteration, but if you\'re a trig or surveying geek, this simple mod will allow you to use it as a surveying tool as well.
If you want the angle measurement to be accurate, once assembled you can use a drop of superglue to fix the wheel in place with respect to the base.  I recommend using the makerscanner software against a flat target like a wall.  Line up the center of the level, measuring the distance with the software.  Then, it\'s a matter of trigonometry to figure out what that angle should be.  The formula is angle = atan(y/x) where y is the measured wall distance and x is the distance from the line level to the camera - when I finish printing my MakerScanner, I\'ll perform this calibration and update the instructions with the specific formula.
Set the angle dial at the calibrated formula and use a drop of superglue to fix it to the base.

I have written this library while I was working on a scad project and thought it might be usefull for someone else. It uses the build in openscad $fn functionality of spheres and cylinders to smooth out cube corners. Version 2014-09-20:
Initial release Version 2014-10-05:
Performance updates

/* Another round corner cube library by towa Version: 2014-10-05 rcorn_cube(size, r, f, center) size : size of the object like in cube-function r as scalar : corner radius of a sphere r[r, h] : corner radius of a sphere and height of an additional, overlayed cylinder r[r, h, t] : corner radius of a sphere, height of an additional cylinder and vertical translation of the cylinder f : number of facets of sphere and cylinder center : false if the object should not be centered Examples: translate([0, -60, 0]) rcorn_cube([50, 40, 30], 10, 8); translate([0, 0, 0]) rcorn_cube([50, 40, 30], [8, 4], 24); translate([0, 60, 0]) rcorn_cube([50, 40, 30], [10, 5, -5], 64); */ // include in your project with "use <rcorn_cube.scad>;" for (i = [0:2]) { translate([i*70, -60, 0]) rcorn_cube([50, 40 - 2*i, 25 - 4*i], 10, fn = 8, center = false); translate([i*70, 0, 0]) rcorn_cube([50, 40 - 4*i, 25 - 8*i], [8, 4], fn = 24, center = false); translate([i*70, 60, 0]) rcorn_cube([50, 40 - 6*i, 25 - 12*i], [10, 5, -5], fn = 64, center = false); } function gz(val) = (val > 0) ? val : 0; module corner_transl(i, size) { translate( [(floor(i ) % 2 == 0) ? -size[0] : size[0], (floor(i/2) % 2 == 0) ? -size[1] : size[1], (floor(i/4) % 2 == 0) ? -size[2] : size[2]]) children(); } module rcorn_cube(size, r, fn, center = true) { //%cube(size, center = center); // check if cube is inside boundaries r = (len(r) == undef) ? [r] : r; // force r to be an array sh = size / 2; // vector with half of the object size shlim = [(r[0] > sh[0]) ? sh[0] : r[0], (r[0] > sh[1]) ? sh[1] : r[0], (r[0] > sh[2]) ? sh[2] : r[0]]; // intersection boundaries // properties of a low resolution sphere rs = r[0] / cos(90 / ceil(fn / 2)); // radius to adjust a given height of a low resolution sphere redg = (ceil(fn / 2) % 2 == 0) ? r[0] : rs; // the edge radius of the low resolution sphere sc = 360 / fn; // corners of a low resolution sphere // horizontal distance the sphere or cylinder has to be moved // inside the object to be in the specified boundaries md = redg * cos(min(abs(135 % sc), abs(135 % sc - sc), abs(135 % sc + sc))); shm = [gz(sh[0] - md), gz(sh[1] - md), gz(sh[2] - r[0])]; // echo(fn, r, redg, rs, md); // debugging hull() { for (i = [0:7]) { translate((center == false) ? sh : [0, 0, 0]) corner_transl(i, shm) // translate to the eight corners of a cube intersection() { // in any case keep box inside boundaries mirror([(floor(i ) % 2 == 0) ? 0 : 1, // first corner points towards the middle (floor(i/2) % 2 == 0) ? 0 : 1, // in this way all 8 corners are arranged symmetrically 0]) rotate([0, 0, 45]) // rotate in such a way that the first corner union() { // points towards the middle of sphere and optional cylinder sphere(r = rs, $fn = fn); // %sphere(r = redg, $fn = fn); // compare with a high resolution sphere for debugging if ((len(r) >= 2) && (r[1] > 0)) { translate([0, 0, (len(r) >= 3) ? r[2] : 0]) cylinder(h = 2*r[1], r = redg, $fn = fn, center = true); } } corner_transl(i, shlim/2) // translate to the eight corners of a cube cube(shlim, center = true); } } } }

remixed_from.title: 8020 clip profiles for snap mount in 8020 and similar extrusions

description.text: Clips that can mount any 15mm thick fan and snap into the slot in an 8020 extrusion.  Can be used with my Arduino board clips to mount a fan over the controller board to keep motor drivers cool.  No hardware required!

Printed with ABS, 0.25 mm first layer, 0.2mm remaining layers, no brim, 30% infill, no support material.  Print two pieces and you can mount any 15mm thick fan on an 8020 extrusion in any position.  Easy modifications include widening the "prongs" to allow mounting thicker fans and thickening the base to stand the fan further from the 8020 rail.

This is the type of really simple hinge you see on a lot of small plastic boxes.
I use it as my standard hinge for any boxes or containers I make.  
They work great.  Little friction and very secure.  
I made this quite awhile ago, but recently shared it with a friend who said I should publish it.   So here it is.

Use at least two.  I often use three on larger containers.   Use as many hinges as you would expect to see on a normally manufactured box.  No more, no less.
This can be scaled up, but it would be prudent to make a larger version of the hinge alone before incorporating it in a larger box.  Sometimes they need to be slightly adjusted.

remixed_from.title: Openscad modules for Open Rail components

description.text: I've got a pile of OpenBeam and Open Rail and was looking for a printer design to adapt. I found Kossel, then the Wolfstock derivative based on Mitsumi extrusion. I decided to adapt Wolfstock to my stuff ..

2-16 .. frame constructed, steel cables added to eliminate twisting between top and bottom triangles I'm just about to the place where I'm ready to melt plastic and cut aluminum ;) I've managed to get the math worked out just about everywhere and the rendering in openscad looks pretty good. I've also removed the individual files, it's too much of a pain keeping up with changes! Check github for the latest, and I'll try and keep a zipfile up to date here. If you want to build in OpenSCAD, download all of the files and put them in one directory, then open and compile yak.scad. You might need a later version to get it to compile (I'm on 2012.07.18). Everything is mostly parameterized .. the stuff you want to change is all in yak_config.scad I suspect I'll end up enhancing the openrail framework with various stiffeners .. See also http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45913 for OpenRail pieces Assemble frame, print rod mounts and end effector, add extruder of choice Adapted from Wolfstock ( https://github.com/wolfmanjm/wolfstock )
and Kossel ( https://github.com/jcrocholl/kossel ) Latest at https://github.com/zeke7237/yak

comments.text: Hi, One useful feature that would be worth adding in to make the orthotic functional to the foot is to add in a wedge to the heel (to tip the heel out or in i.e. supinate or pronate the foot). There could be two types, 1 with the maximum thickness on the inner heel surface and 1 with maximum thickness at outer heel surface. There are a few variations in thickness that could be used, probably starting with 3mm then incrementally mm by mm up to around 9mm shoudl be enough. If this could be added in to the Customizer of thingiverse it would be very cool! The reason this is useful is that orthotics dont tend to work by "supporting the arch" as previosuly thought (in the 50's) but by applying a force to the sustentaculum tali of the foot i.e. by tipping the heel. Hope this helps. Democratize Orthotics.

title: 12mm Carbon Tube Anti Vibration Motor Mount Clamps

description.text:
This is an anti-vibe mount for 12mm carbon tubes. You can simply insert an o-ring in the spare-outs and mount your motors with these clamps.
This way the motor vibration doesn't directly transfer to the carbon tube but there's an insulation between. Whether this actually helps reducing overall vibration still has to be tested.
Actually the more mass directly connected to the motors, the better, but there are some multirotor producers who implemented this design already and so I wanted to try it out.... :)

description.text: After few unlucky intents on freeCAD I finally found the best way to pass the sound efficiently with a good looking passive speaker design. This "round Speaker" is simple combination of typical basic freeCAD parts forms creation, sphere, cones and cube. Believe me, I am not an engineer, so I can not guarantee any powerful speaker sound. If you need to enjoy your music in a very personal intimate way, this really may help you. I have no interest on control the phone or plug the power cable, just listen my music. The sound is very directional and I think some high notes get lost into the PLA material use. The piece takes near 10m of 3mm filament using 4 vertical layers  and 25% of infill with .25 mm layers height. Printing time is about 5:40 hrs on my Velleman K8200. Finally, it is only usable with iPhone 5 and 5s, do not think 5C fit it neither iPhone 4 family, may be iPod 5 generation, but does not have one to test it.

The draw need to be rotated to stand up on his base. I rotate X -90 and ask repetierHost to laid flat on bed. This way the piece print without any problem. No try to print it any other way. You can do the way you prefer, just make the base laid flat on you printer bed.

title: 808 #16 camera box with wide angle lens and mobile phone battery
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I wanted longer battery life and a wide angle lens for my 808 #16 keyring camera so made this little box. May fit other 808 cameras but I'm not sure.

This is an early work in progress so please don't expect too much from it if you decide to try it out. I won't upload fixed printable STL files for every version, you can create those yourself if you wish using the included SketchUp file.Your printer will need to be set up pretty well to print this item properly.

-Uses my wide angle lens files to create a perfect hole for the lens to sit in. thing:470031
-Fits a Nokia BLB-2 3.6V 700mah battery to make the camera run as long as it takes to fill up a 32gb microsd card.
-Please recharge your phone battery using your original mobile phone and phone charger, NOT inside the box. I am not responsible for you burning down your house when trying to recharge it using the camera's usb cable or whatever method you choose to use.
-You will need to remove the internal battery from the camera and extend some wires down into the battery compartment. Flat copper connections are advised and should be glued into the small recesses.

Things to do:
-Improve ease of battery terminal access
-Access panels (battery and lid) need redoing
-spit & polish
-...etc.

Changelog:
V2 19/9/14 (as per photos)
-Added hinge mechanism for lid.
-Added battery flap
V3 21/9/14
-Improved battery flap
-Battery should now move in and out smoothly
-Created larger channel for easier battery wire installation
V3.1
-Button holes added to lid
-Smoother access hinges
V3.2 22/9/14
-Recessed button area
-Lid hinge fixed
-Lid resized to fit properly
-Strengthened wide angle lens recess
V3.3
-slightly cleaned up model
-Repositioned battery wire channel for easier installation of terminals
-Added wire channel for neater look
-Raised bridge area to protect the lens when attached
V3.42 24/9/14
-Stronger bridge area
-Slight tweaks
V3.44 27/9/14
-Changed the lid to be more secure. Now requires a small flat bladed (jewellers type) screwdriver (or a bent paperclip) to remove it. Insert into hole at lens end and push screwdriver tip away from lens to unclip.
Have any suggestions? Please let me know.
100% infill along with a heated bed recommended. Printed in PLA.

Required:
-808 #16 keyring camera
-microsd card
-wide angle 0.67x lens
-common Nokia BLB-2 battery
-2x wires (1x red, 1x black are preferable)
-2x copper or thin steel contact points (pieces of very thin flat metal 8x3mm)
-soldering iron + solder
-needle-nosed pliers
-glue
Build Instructions:

-feed wires down through the connecting channel into the bottom battery area
-bend your thin contact point metal in half with pliers then two more bends (so it looks like the picture)
-solder contact points to the end of each wire
-put a dab of glue into the slight recessed areas in the battery compartment then press the contact points into them using a long thin sturdy item (like a flat bottomed pencil) making sure to attach the red wire (positive) closest to the connecting channel hole
-remove the original battery from inside the camera (remember which is connected to red and which is black)
-cut wires to length
-solder the other ends to the camera internal battery connectors (make sure of correct polarity), or if your original battery came with a connector attach your wires to that
-make sure lens hole is large enough to push lens all the way in, trim edges with a sharp knife if not quite a perfect fit
-hot-glue the lens into lens hole
-attach top lid panel
-insert charged battery (always recharge the battery in it's original intended device, never via the 808 camera!)
-attach battery door
-done

comments.text: Actually, charging the nokia battery via the camera usb will NOT burn your house ! To check whether or not lithium batteries are charged, electronic devices check the battery voltage. ALL lithium batteries are considered as charged at 4.2V, no matter the size of it :) don't make your life harder; you can even wire the two batteries in parallel (the orginal and the nokia one), you will never get any issue !
comments.author: Bynokel

comments.text:
That's correct... assuming the person who is connecting it all up has done it properly. Not everyone is careful, and some may make mistakes. I basically just put that instead of a disclaimer. If someone dribbles solder all over the place, there's a short, or if the battery doesn't include an overvoltage protection circuit (like many cheap far-east produced batteries that are sold online), then these can cause a fire. As this camera box can possibly be used with various sizes and types of batteries, it's better to be safe than sorry.
I will change the text to make it clearer. :)

description.text: It's the 4-pin (+5VDC, +12VDC, GND GND) disk systems (HDD, CD-ROM) power plug for socket contacts.  I had a project I was using just the sockets for, and decided to model this as an exercise.  Features include treads and wings for easy removal, and a pin 1 marker.  It looks swell!  Sometimes called a "Molex plug," it is made by many different manufacturers.

Print it solid, with small layers for good accuracy. It can print without support, even though there is a small overhang.
If you print this in Nylon (the native material for this type of plug), let me know. :-)

title: Plate for goodluckbuy brushless gimbal for front mounting

description.text: If you have the cheap 2-axis gimbal from goodluckbuy and want to mount it forward-facing on your quad/tri/hex/octo/motorcycle/racing boat, then you've come to the right place.

This plate replaces the vibration damper top plate with an extended version, so you can hang your gimbal up front of you multirotor.
All that is needed is one foam earplug for additional stabilisation and vibration dampening.
I simply glued the earplug to the back of the roll motor where it would else touch my copter frame.
Because the gimbal weight is now pulling on the back two damper balls instead of compressing them, I witnessed a little bit more additional vibrations than convenient, so I had to stabilize the roll motor with this earplug. Now it's all good.
First version of this plate was exactly as thick as the original aluminium plate, but this turned out too thin and wobbly, so this version is a bit thicker. Maybe it would help to still make it thicker, but I'm content with it right now.
It won't win any design contest, it's just a Frankenstein kind of mod, but does the job.
There's a basic version and a version with an integrated fpv-cam mount I stole from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:238109.
In order to use it you have to print out the actual cam case from there, I only integrated the holder into my plate.
The additional four holes in the middle of the plate were put there to attach a 3-axis servo gimbal from hobbyking for my headtracker.
I found out, though, that the vibrations of the three servos are not exactly supportive of the smooth functioning of the brushless gimbal.

Bird pendant generator.
First Step, open bird shaper:
http://chaaawa.com/forthebirds
 
 
From the opening angle of his tail, the number of feathers on it, to the ratio of separation between upper and lower part of his beak: everything is parametric.
That makes a lot... hence the graphical assistant to help you in this task !
Designed by Lætitia

Design the main shape of your pendant in the Bird Shaper
Paste the output in Customizer and fine tune the details (toes, ring...)
 
Bird Shaper also available in .zip for offline use.
 
Google Swiffy output (for devices without flash player) is barely functionnal. A full rewrite is required for an useable html version.

comments.text: Very cool idea and thank you for posting!  I tried to print it scale a couple of times using a Makerbot replicator 2 with PLA.  The first time, the legs got mangled early on.  I then tried to print using rafting which worked until i tried to remove the rafting and broke off the tail.  What would be the best way to thicken up the legs and tail?  the "Body Thickness" parameter seems to only increase the tail thickness slightly and legs not at all. Do you think increasing layer height might help?  Thanks again for sharing your awesome project!
comments.author: jennylc

comments.text:
Thanks.
You can thicken the legs by increasing "legs_diameter" which is the width and height of them (try 2.4 for example, you may want to increase "toes_length" after that).
The tail thickness is the body thickness minus "rounding" (put it to 0 and you get a flat bird with the tail as thick as the body).
"layer_height" is the thickness of slices used to build the rounding.

Literally in the name, this scooter took only a week to build and it is road worthy! I haven't seen another 3D printed scooters on Thingiverse so this shall be the first!

For the horizontal part of the handle bars use a 18 mm diameter pole cut however long you want. And for the vertical handle bars use a 16 mm diameter pole, cut to the height you need. For the support under the deck use a 2X1 (inches) piece of wood cut after you put the 5 deck parts on. The deck parts go, first the smallest one with the thicker/thinner then thicker walls, the the two small normal decks, the the biggest one, then the one with the wheel holder. drill holes through the top of the decks into the support wood. Then put the diagonal part with the hole in one side on the first smallest part and drill accordingly. Take the credit card like part and put it under the support wood, screw through it into the thick parts of the first (smallest) part. put the vertical smaller pole into the n shaped front wheel holder and use lots of epoxy. Take the 18 mm pole and cut another half a foot, and glue it so its through the diagonal front piece so there's exactly 1 cm coming out the bottom. Put a washer under where the 1 cm of pole comes out, that will help support.put the vertical pole with the n wheel holder through the front tube and attach the handle bar holder (the cube with the 3 holes in it) and glue that on. Then centre the horizontal handle bar pole in the handle bar holder and glue. Take roller blade wheels and put them where it look like they should go! Congrats! Now how safe do you feel riding a scooter designed by a 13 year old?

The monument includes a cap piece sized to hold a wargaming or role-playing miniature of your choice, whether commercial or from elsewhere on Thingiverse..
Spray with stone texture paint for extra effect.

title: NXT Motor Drive to Tetrix Hub connector

description.text:
Fairly securely connects a LEGO NXT Motor to a Tetrix axle hub, which can be used to connect Tetrix gears, sprockets, and channels. Uses standard technic pins and tetrix screws and nuts.
Prints flat without supports.
Reasonably secure (as secure as 4 technic pins can be), but conceivably could be knocked off by a very hard shot from an opposing FTC robot, so you might want to use an axle through the hub and secure the opposite end with a bushing and another Tetrix channel if you're concerned about combat-readiness.

Print flat. Install screws through the part first and into the hub or other Tetrix part. Then insert technic pins into NXT motor and attach.
Can be a tricky print since the spacing between the screw holes and the pin holes is quite small, but surprisingly it printed fine and seems strong.

description.text:
Here is a Bixler hatch mount for the rear fuselage. Cut a wedge shape hole on the top side large enough to hold the wedge. Cram all your electronics in then use a ziptie to secure it to the fuse. The FRSky Antenna Holder is derived from Carbo's original antenna holder found here... www.thingiverse.com/thing:258146

Test printed at .1mm layer height on my Makerbot Replicator 2 in PLA with raft (.1mm prints just don't turn out well for me without raft).
OLD
I got a better fit wtih Front_Bezel1: Front_Bezel is slightly smaller than Front_Bezel1, and the extrusion width of your printer might make the mount too small. You can also experiment with X/Y stretching (like 1% or so) to make it fit snugger or looser. I include four counter-sink screw holes so you can use some 2-56 flat heads and they should sit flush and clean. I also include the .123dx solids file with some workshop stuff in it.
I should follow up with a small desktop monitor stand (think, chat window or pandora side-screen) and some other projects, but the front bezel would be a common part among them with this little LCD panel.

This is a large (2.5kg with hardware, ~504030 cm) all wheel drive 'platform' for GPS/SLAM experimentation. There is some footage of it using GPS to navigate here: http://youtu.be/Q1CUnUzaENc and using LIDAR to avoid obstacles (but not phone cameras) here: http://youtu.be/v2fPF3EMCtM The EOP is designed to:
  • be printed on a printer with build volume 140mm width, 140mm depth, 135mm height i.e. Up Plus, makerbot or most hobby printers should suffice, but you know the limits of your own printer!!!
  • to be very flexible. there is a basic chassis. Parts click on and off (mostly - some need bolts and nuts) and you can add or modify the accessories (LCD, breakout boards, gopro/virb mount etc) and suspension.
  • uses skid steer (see motor/battery/relay combination I use below to make this work at this weight). It works very well - will climb until it flips over.
    • I have included the CAD file (rhino .3dm) to aid modification (UPDATED 13OCT2014).

I can't help you with coding or wiring right now. I will upload better assembly instructions later. For now there's photos!!!!
IMPORTANT NOTE 1: the suspension braces and 'motor stiffening' (1 rear, 1 front, = bracing between 2 motors) are critical pieces. They are all essential if you don't want it to fold in half!
IMPORTANT NOTE 2: you have to print 3 x the chassis member, then glue this together. I sanded mine to make the faces perfectly flat. If you do this right it will be strong enough. The plastic will break before the joint.
THE REST:
It does print easily. I needed no special tricks, but suggest you print the 'working' surfaces of the suspension facing up so they will be smooth and precise as possible.
The base design has Arduino standard sized carriers and a carrier for an accessible Lidar, but I've included the rhino .3dm so you can change any part to suit your hardware.
Some glueing and drilling and screwing is required.
SMALL PROBLEM: The side carrier that is needed to fit the longer Mega Arduino is too big to print on my printer (the original for an 'Uno' lets the corners of the Mega just touch the wheels at max. axle articulation).
THE FIX: get a bigger printer, or, you can use a heat gun to adjust the inclination of your the arduino side carriers to suit the Mega. How? Set the hot air gun to 250 degrees (or guess if you can;t do that), put a blank proto shield in the carrier to make the receiver hold its shape, heat the place you want to bend (around 10-15 secs should do - it goes shiny), then bend to suit the angle you need. Yes, this does work! See Photo. Here's the hardware I have on my prototype:
Arduino Mega
Compass/Accel: Adafruit Triple-axis Accelerometer+Magnetometer (Compass) Board - LSM303
LCD: Adafruit ST7735
Motors: 04 x MEC-30090 : 75:1 Metal Gearmotor 25Dx54L mm
Motor brackets aluminium: 2 x Pololu 25D mm Metal Gearmotor Bracket Pair
Relays: MCU-60121 Pololu Basic SPDT Relay Carrier with 12VDC
Battery: NiMh 6.2V
GPS: GPS Shield with SD card socket for Arduino PS_SDV2B_P3
Cliff detection: 4 x IR distance sensor (<80cm)(GP2Y0A21YK0F)
LIDAR: Robo Peak 360 Degree Laser Scanner Development Kit (RPLIDAR)
Wheels: Dagu Wild Thumper Wheels - 4 Pack Chrome
Springs: 9mm dia. X 35mm (unloaded). Number: 4 to 12, depending on load

This is another design I had made for the simple bag clip published earlier at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45704
I'm posting this now based on the feedback received from the original design, and was wondering if maybe this is a better version? I print using a uPrint SE+ printer at Kishwaukee College in Malta, Il. where I'm a C.N.C./Machinist/Tooling Design student. The stl processor and print manager is called CatalystEX 4.1, and I normally print at a resolution of 0.010", solid infill and with all support material being automatically managed by the printing software. Stl and SolidWorks sldprt files are included - use them anyway you'd like, all I ask is that you please let me know if you print one and find it useful or have any other feedback for me. Thanks!
Paul
Fold over or twist up the open portion of the bag you'd like to have held closed and slide the clip over the folded opening or the twisted up part to hold in place. Simple, quick and useful.

title: Tie Interceptor for Casual X-Wing Gaming

description.text:
This model is a derivative of Kolo33's Tie Interceptor (thanks for the great starting point!). The main thing I have done to the model is to adjust the proportions to be more in line with models in the X-Wing game.  
I also recreated the connector so that it wraps around the stand a little differently (I think better), and I've provided a simple raft to use in situations where one is needed (see below).  
The "repositioned" version of the model is included only so I get a better Thingiverse image :).
I printed this using Simplify3D, a MakerBot R2X, and ToyBuilder Labs Grey filament. I use a separate first layer at 0.3mm (with the included raft), then print the remainder at 0.1mm layers.

Display your geek side proudly! Are you a Marvel fan? Show the world! Are you a DC addict? Let the people see! Do you read obscure Image comics that no one has ever heard of? Show them what they are missing!
Hang your comics on the wall, without using tacks!
I use small strips of 2 sided tape to stick them to the wall. Once you stick them to the wall, press and hold each corner for several seconds, you don't want it falling off. I would recommend one mount per each corner of comic. Probably best to test this with less-valuable comics for a couple of months before you display anything valuable!

description.text:
UPDATE: New version uploaded.
v1.1 - Enlarged the slots to correctly fit a 6/32" nut.
This is a remix of MarkBenson's Drill Press for Hobby Drill.
This base incorporates 2 slot for clamping down your project.
Slots are for 6/32" screws that are 10mm long. The larger slots on the bottom are for the nut to fit tight so you don't have hold them while adjusting the Clamps.
I also elongated the pass through for different setups.
Instructions - See Instructions tab.
P.S.: This "Thing" will not be here forever. I hate Makerbot/Thingiverse and will post this up on Youmagine and other 3D hosts. Once I have this model uploaded elsewhere, it will be deleted from here and a link added to the other hosts.
UPDATE: Added Solidworks files.

Print the base with 20% infill, 2 shells. I would also recommend using support due to the over hangs on the slots and the hole for the nut. Dimensions: 110mm x 125mm
Print the clamp with at least 80% infill and 2+shells. The more infill and shells the stronger it will be.

description.text:
This was just me playing around with OpenSCAD, trying to make something sculpture-y and not necessarily functional.
I haven't printed this one yet, and I'm not sure of its printworthiness.
OpenSCAD render time was just short of 2 hours on my machine.

Took a basic profile in Illustrator, imported into OpenSCAD with a linear_extrude + scale. Revolved that until I had a complete rotation and then did a difference() with another rotate_extrude that created the hourglass shape.
I've attached the basic STL file that creates all the rotational shapes in addition to the OpenSCAD file. The OpenSCAD file references this STL file so you'll need it to complete the render.
I'm still not a pro with OpenSCAD, just playing around.

description.text:
A spiral themed chess set that can be printed without supports. I modeled this myself and I am currently in the process of printing a set. Any criticism is welcome and appreciated.   
This has been a project I have been working on since I first got my printer. I wanted to develop something that could not be manufactured by any other process other than 3D Printing. I was stuck for a while on how to make the Knight, but I am finally happy enough with all of the models to publish it to the public.  
Since this set has now been successfully printed, I am no longer marking is as a work-in-progress. If I make significant changes in the future, I will likely upload it as a new file.

Printed on a Makerfarm 8" i3v in PLA at 0.20mm layer height. Each print took some time (about 2hr) as they are pretty large pieces, so be prepared for a bit of a long print time. You could scale them down to 75% or so if you are looking for a smaller set.  
No supports required!

With my re-imaginationed pieces at one side and someone elses at the other, I do not want to design either Roman, Muslim, Crusader, etctera pieces as I have no way to identify with the cultures and do not want to post anything potentially controvercial, but this is a terrific base to start with and I would love to see other makers reiImaginings and collect/print them for my own use and enjoyment. comments.text: The trick is you need to print more than one piece at a time to prevent the ooze. I attempted only printing the bishop, but as it got close to the middle of the print I started seeing the ooze.  So I lowered my temp and then the part became brittle (improper adhesion). I then raised the temp to normal for my PLA and added another part. still saw some ooze but it was better.  So I then lowered my run speed to 70%. At this point, I switched to my mattercontrol app and it printed out perfect,. No strings, ooze, clean sharp edges on the spirals. then I added the rest of the pieces that I have not printed, moved to normal speed (100%) and everything is perfect.

comments.text: Experiment #1: I changed the infill from 20% to 30%, still 90mm/sec, still 150um layer height, and the part didn't break. comments.text:
Printed very well without support and almost no strings or artefacts, found that printing as many as possible at once helped with speed. If just printing a single one my software slowed the layer speed right down so it all cooled down.
Ended up printing 8 pieces at a time and scaled the model down to 50% size and still printed without any issues taking just over an hour.
This is a very cool idea and model that really show off the ability of a 3d printer!

title: Kossel Mini Power Switch with Voltmeter Plate

description.text: I wanted to have a little 3 digit LED voltmeter next to my KM power switch and those things just so happen to fit snugly between the extrusions on the base! this plate bolts down in the corners and holds a roughly 12x27mm switch and your run-of-the-mill Chinese 3 digit LED voltmeter like http://www.ebay.com/itm/141049350659?_trksid=p2059210.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT. on the back side there is a slight indentation for the voltmeter to fit into, I used a couple dabs of superglue to retain it but honestly you may not need it, its a tight fit. Then jut wire the voltmeter to the power after the switch so this way it is on with the rest of the electronics and doubles as a power light! I later plan to make something similar for the AUX power input for my heated bed circuit and a red voltmeter, stay tuned.

Print with a translucent filament like clear ABS, natural PLA or PET for best results. I used clear PLA and even with 1mm of solid infill the digits are still bright and sharp. requires 4 3x5mm screws and 4 nuts in the bottom extrusions.

This is a derivative work of the iris box (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4458) by msruggles.
I tried to print msruggles's iris box for my son, but failed. I think my bot is not so well-tuned that it simply cannot handle the tiny gears well, also my self-built HBP has a limited effective building area for like 80mm x80mm including the raft. So I redesigned the box to be more fool-bot friendly. Small enough in size, and no tiny gear teeth. If you have trouble printing the iris box, try this one.

• The whole structure follows msruggles's design.
  • The 5 shutters are arranged in one print, but remember to skeinforge this file with support material set to "exteriors only". There's a pin for each shutter that need support to print.
  • Each pin goes in a slot in the "ring" part. The pins and the slots also interlock so that you can't over-turn the ring when the shutters were fully opened.
  • I simply used some filament to bolt the shutters and weld it on the "cover" with a soldering iron.
    • P.S. I also made a little pin on the "ring" to lock it on the "box" when shutters were fully closed. However, I may have left so little tolerance between "box" and "ring" that the lock is not necessary needed.

Okay, one last simple bag clip design from me. This one features two complete loops, and is the design I personally found the least useful of the three I've made.
Some people I made this design for loved them however, so I figured I might as well put it up here and see what you guys think. The previous two are http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45704 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:47053 For information, I use a uPrint SE+ printer that the college I go to is nice enough to let me play with (alot!) My stl processing and print management is done with CadalystEX 4.1 that is included with the printer. I print at a resolution of 0.010", solid infill and I let the software determine the support material. Stl and Solidworks sldprt files are included - use them however you'd like. All I ask is that if you print out one or more of these simple bag clips I've designed, please leave a comment here or email me at [email protected] to let me know what you think, or if you can think of any improvements. Thanks!
Paul
Fold over or twist up the open end of the bag you'd like to have held shut, and simply slide the clip in place to hold. Simple, quick, cheap & useful.

comments.text: I put a 40mm fan across the extruder and found it to be a little too much cooling for the all metal hot end. When printing ABS the heater was sruggling to get up to temperature with that big fan on. This resolved that issue, has the bonus that I can close it to heat it up faster when I start warming things up. Can also be useful for slowing the fan at certain times to prevent cooling the bed during the first layer or so on some large ABS prints. Could be scaled up for 50mm also.
